title: Double Negation Introduction
description:
Prove that any proposition implies its double negation: if `P` holds, then `P` cannot be refuted.

**Goal:** `forall P : Prop, P -> ~~P`

Recall that `~P` is defined as `P -> False` in Coq, so `~~P` is `(P -> False) -> False`. You need to show that assuming both `P` and `~P` leads to a contradiction.
hints: Use `intros` to introduce `P`, a proof `HP` of `P`, and a proof `HnP` of `~P` (i.e., `P -> False`)
You now have a contradiction: `HnP` says `P` is false, but `HP` says `P` is true. Use `apply HnP` to reduce the goal to `P`
prelude: (* No imports needed for this basic logic proof *)
template:
Theorem not_not_intro : forall P : Prop, P -> ~~P.
Proof.
  (* Your proof here *)
Admitted.
solution:
Theorem not_not_intro : forall P : Prop, P -> ~~P.
Proof.
  intros P HP HnP.
  apply HnP.
  exact HP.
Qed.
